awd_abstract_narration:
Information theory studies the fundamental laws that govern information processing systems. For instance, the Shannon Capacity of a noisy channel is the largest rate (in bits per channel use) that bits can be reliably communicated. Information theory has had an enormous impact on how information is acquired, processed, compressed, and transmitted. Examples include channel coding and data compression, both of which are used extensively in Internet and cellular communications. This project focuses on connections between performance and codebook symmetry. One part focuses on using symmetry to help low-complexity decoders achieve near-optimum performance for codes relevant to 5G cellular standards. This project will also train several graduate students, hence an important broader impact of this project is the production of highly-trained workers in electrical engineering and computer science.

Many theoretical results in information theory use random codebooks to encode messages. Researchers have long sought families of deterministic algebraic codes that provably achieve capacity. In a recent breakthrough, the PI and his coauthors showed that sequences of sufficiently symmetric codes achieve capacity on the binary erasure channel. Since Reed-Muller codes satisfy the required symmetry condition, we now know that such a code family was discovered by Muller in 1954, only 6 years after Shannon's introduction of channel capacity! The project focuses on whether symmetric codebooks can be used in more general settings to approach information-theoretic limits. In particular, the goals are to determine: (i) How general is the phenomenon of capacity via symmetry? (ii) What performance gains can be achieved in practice by exploiting symmetries? (iii) Can symmetry be utilized to approach the information-theoretic limits of other problems?

por.por_cntn:
Since its introduction by Claude Shannon in 1948, the field of information theory has had enormous impact on the way that information is acquired, processed, compressed, and transmitted.  Shannon?s work characterized a number of fundamental information-processing limits including the maximum rate of compression for random sources (e.g., the limit of lossless compression for files) and the maximum rate of information transmission over noisy channels (e.g., how fast data can be accessed through wifi).  The maximum rate, measured in information bits per channel use, of reliable communication over a noisy channel is called the channel capacity.

After the introduction of channel capacity, information theorists began searching for families of algebraic codes that provably achieve capacity on memoryless channels.  Until recently, positive results had only been established in special cases.  Prior to 2016, these special cases required a sequence of channels where the capacity converges to 0 or 1.  In 2016, a new approach was used to show that the family of Reed-Muller codes achieves capacity on the binary erasure channel. While this was important breakthrough, the binary erasure channel still represents a special case which is not relevant for practical applications like wireless communications.  However, in a surprising twist, the new result relied only on the symmetry of the code and this gave rise to the title of this project, ?Capacity via Symmetry?.

In recent breakthrough work supported by this grant, item PIs have shown that Reed-Muller codes achieve capacity ? that is, that they achieve the maximum rate of information transmission ? on a large family of channels known as binary memoryless symmetric (BMS) channels.  Thus, we now know that a family of algebraic codes that achieves capacity on any BMS channel was discovered by Muller in 1954, only 6 years Shannon?s seminal paper. This also resolves a long-standing open question in information theory and answers one of the open questions posed in the proposal for this project.  It turns out that the path taken by the new proof is somewhat different from the erasure channel case and it relies on code properties beyond symmetry.  However, it is not clear if this is fundamental (e.g., symmetry is not sufficient to achieve capacity on general BMS channels) or if our understanding of this problem is not yet sophisticated enough to establish the same result using only symmetry.

An interesting consequence of the new result is that quantum Reed-Muller codes can achieve the coherent information rate on quantum Pauli error channels where X and Z errors occur independently with the same probability.  This answers another open question posed in the proposal for this project.

This project also studied whether code symmetry could be used to improve the performance of short codes used in practice.  Using an iterative decoder motivated by code symmetry, the results of this research show that short Reed-Muller codes can be decoded with good performance by using all minimum-weight parity checks.  This grant also allowed us to explore additional decoding methods.  Unfortunately, the complexity of these methods was still too large to be practical.  However, partly motivated by our results, a few other groups have recently found efficient decoders that use code symmetry to improve decoding performance with moderate complexity.

The intellectual and broader impact of this project stems from a few different things.  First, this project supported our recent work that resolves a long-standing problem in information theory. Second, as mentioned above, the results of this research have already had some impact of the theory and practice of short block codes for wireless communications.  Third, the new techniques used in the recent proof for Reed-Muller codes are expected to have impact on the study of high-dimensional inference problems in statistics and machine learning. Finally, an important broader impact of this research is the training of three graduate students, one of whom is a woman.
